content.title: Clear-Cut Call: Responding To God
content.introtext: 'When I heard these words I sat down and wept...' Nehemiah 1:4 NRS<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150812.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Don’t feel like you’ve ever heard God’s clear–cut call for you? When you get an unshakeable sense of ‘I want to see change’ deep inside, you’re on to something. You might not feel like that about a particular issue right now but keep praying and you will. Let’s see what Nehemiah did when he heard God call him. The call to Nehemiah began with terrible news. God’s people were suffering and His holy city was destroyed. Nehemiah’s response was to sit down and weep. Bawl his eyes out. This is instinctive, natural and right. We talk a lot about being joyful in Church, but the Bible is also full of people weeping in response to the suffering they see. Their tears reflect God’s pain. When we see suffering, it *should* hurt us when we know it goes against the grain of God’s will for the world. And, before Nehemiah could even respond in sorrow, he had to hear the news. In the same way, we have to hear before we can respond. And to hear, we have to listen. We have to open our ears and hearts to news of places and people in need. We have to allow ourselves to be stirred, to feel discomfort. But, crucially, we’ve then got to follow it with action. Compassion is not just a feeling, it’s a response. Pick a situation around you or a story in the news you think needs to change, and take it to God and ask Him how and when you should get involved. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chr 16-18, Mark 5:21-30, Ps 119:49-56, Prov 21:4-6 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67728&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Clear-Cut Call: Asking For Help
content.introtext: 'If it pleases the King... I ask...' Nehemiah 2:5 NRS <br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150813.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Bring back to mind the situation or person you spent time thinking about yesterday. Time to work out how to respond. Nehemiah’s got this next step down. He asked for help, and not just from anyone. He went to the highest human authority available—the king. He felt no shame about appealing on behalf of his people to someone with some downright intimidating cred. Got a person or place on your heart? Don’t be ashamed to ask for help—or be too proud to ask those with power to help you. Some (in fact, most) tasks in God’s Kingdom will need more than a one–man band approach. Nehemiah knew he was doing the work of God, but he also knew that there were power structures in place that he had to work with to bring about Godly change. What’s more, the king he approached wasn’t a follower of God. The connections God will give you when you say ‘yes’ to His plan might not be ones you expect. Be open to His surprises. When God makes a way, He makes a way. So then, back to that situation or person you thought of yesterday. Who could you go to for help as you let God work in you? Is there someone in authority—a boss, a relative, a politician—you could ask? What support could they offer you? Are you brave enough to get on it? Share your concern for this place or person with at least one authority figure this week, and ask them for advice and support. You might be surprised by what they can do, and what support they offer you. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chr 19:1-23:20, Mark 5:31-43, Ps 119:57-64, Prov 21:7-9 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67729&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Clear-Cut Call: Get To Work
content.introtext: '...They replied, "Let us start rebuilding." So they began this good work.' Nehemiah 2:18 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150814.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Yesterday, we looked at sharing our call with others. After that, the best advice any of us will hear is simply: ‘make a start’. Taking the plunge is what stops your call from just being a dead–end. So why don’t we? We tell ourselves we don’t have the right things in place. Like: (1) ‘I’m not qualified’? Well, Kingdom work usually involves called (*not* qualified) people doing things they never dreamt of. (2) ‘People aren’t agreeing with me’? We’ll get into this tomorrow, but for now, know this: God’s people always get flak. David’s own brother took pot–shots at him before the Goliath fight, even calling him ‘evil’ (1 Samuel 17:28). (3) And what about ‘the timing isn’t right just yet’? Ecclesiastes 11:4 NIV says: ‘<em>Whoever watches the wind will not plant; whoever looks at the clouds will not reap</em>.’ If you’re looking for a sign that the time is right, you might end up missing it. Whatever you need, don’t be afraid to ask. Nehemiah went for it—he shared his plan with some friends, got them to commit, and then they began. In fact, the whole of chapter 3 is just a list of the different people who helped Nehemiah in different ways. He was humble enough to ask for help, and bold enough to confidently share his plan, knowing that it was worthwhile. Can you support a Christian group who are facing seriously difficult opposition and spreading the Gospel anyway? Prayer is a significant need. Consider an organisation like opendoors.org.au </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chr 23:21-26:19, Mark 6:1-13, Ps 119:65-72, Prov 21:10-13 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67730&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Clear-Cut Call: Unfamiliar Paths
content.introtext: 'Lord, let Your ear be attentive to the prayer of this Your servant...' Nehemiah 1:11 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150815.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Whether you have a clear–cut plan for the future or not, it’s always best to bring whatever we have to God in prayer. Often we’ve got a–million–and–one possible ideas for the future: excitement, back–up plans, ‘when I’ve got enough money’ plans... If that’s the boat you’re in, God will help you to narrow down the options, if you reciprocate that attentive ear thing (check out today’s verse), and listen right back to Him. Or perhaps, like a lot of us, you’re the opposite. The ‘what are you doing next year?’ question is one that haunts a lot of us, mostly because we’re pretty bad at getting hold of ideas for the futures. Wherever we find ourselves, it’s likely we’ll all benefit from a reminder: ‘…<em>along unfamiliar paths I will guide them; I will turn the darkness into light be-fore them and make the rough places smooth. These are the things I will do; I will not forsake them</em>.’ (Isaiah 42:16 NIV) Whether the ‘darkness’ is the sea of choices you feel you have to wade through, or a sense of blankness about the future, God will be there. We’ll be taking a last look at Nehemiah’s wall–building capers tomorrow, but for now, remember how much prayer he put in before he went along with God’s plan. Be encouraged: it’s not an overnight process. Just bring what you have before Him, and leave the ball in His court. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Chr 26:20-29:30, Mark 6:14-29, Ps 119:73-80, Prov 21:14-16 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67731&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Clear-Cut Call: Swords and Trowels
content.introtext: '...Those who carried materials did their work with one hand and held a weapon in the other.' Nehemiah 4:17 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150816.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>So, Nehemiah took on God’s mission to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem. Good on him. Couldn’t be much better and easier, right? Hmmm. Actually, he faced pretty tough opposition: heavy criticism and even threats to his life. The reality is, when we follow out a call God has for our lives (no matter how big or small), there may be opposition. You could find that you’ll be struggling to carry out that call. Opposition is exactly what Nehemiah’s workers were ready for; they were building with a sword in one hand and a trowel in the other. When you’ve got a deep sense of God’s approval and conviction for a call, it’s important to get yourself grounded in it. Keeping a journal of the times you’ve prayed, and the ways you’ve found God responds, is a good way of doing this (hey, if you haven’t got a journal, maybe it’s time to splash out on one?), as well as listing some helpful Bible verses. Then, when you find yourself facing opposition, maybe even from your own doubts, those words will become your Ephesians 6:17 style defence. Let’s take the whole ‘following God’s call’ thing seriously. We humans come alive when God gives us a mission. It’s so worth catching hold of God’s short and long term plans for our lives. Write a Bible verse about God’s protection down (let’s call it your sword–verse). Write one about how to build your life around Him on another piece of paper (your trowel–verse). Hold one in each hand, and pray for Him to direct you in His plan. Carry the verses with you today. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Jer 31:31-37, Heb 8:1-13 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67732&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Mixed Motives
content.introtext: 'Amaziah did what was pleasing in the Lord's sight, but not wholeheartedly.' 2 Chronicles 25:2 NLT<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150817.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Question: can we do things that God wants in a way which doesn’t put Him first? Yes, we can. This is exactly what 2 Chronicles tells us King Amaziah did. On the outside, he was doing all the right things, but his heart wasn’t in it. His heart was on his own agenda, his own desires. Hmmm. What’s that mean, then? First, a heart turned towards God, and towards serving others, is one that is wide open to God’s blessings. Our motives for doing things are, so often, mixed. The challenge for us, then, is this: ‘<em>Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God</em>.’ (Matthew 5:8 NIV) In our service, if we strip back the bits that point to us rather than Him, we’re clearing up the airwaves to see Him more clearly and let His blessings in. It’s always good to consider where our heart is when we give. How often have we thought: ‘This will make me look good. I wonder how many people saw me do that?’ The beauty of it is that we don’t need to give so God will mark off a few more brownie points for us on a ticklist. ‘<em>God loves a cheerful giver</em>.’ (2 Corinthians 9:7 NIV) He really does. The giving of our money, time and energy can be from gratitude to His love for us. That’s a win–win for everyone involved—we don’t need to impress anyone, and our lives become bigger. So, let’s make sure our motives for giving are right. Assess your giving, assess your motives, and pray them all through. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chr 1-4, Mark 6:30-44, Ps 119:81-88, Prov 21:17-19 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67733&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Wise Up!
content.introtext: 'Wise people are rewarded...' Proverbs 14:24 GNT<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150818.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>A (very) brief summary of Proverbs 14: wisdom is the best. Without it, you’re like someone who tears their house down (verse 1), will ‘believe anything’ (verse 15), and have no qualms about making rash decisions that don’t honour God (verse 16). Sounds like it might be useful, then. As well as the big–scale school/university/work decisions we make, we are faced with hundreds of different everyday courses of action to take ourselves. Whether it’s that link you shouldn’t click, that impulse buy you didn’t need, that drinking game your flatmates are playing, it’s wisdom that gives us an insight into what will help us to build our lives best. Essentially, being wise will help us to keep putting God (and others) first, creating a solid foundation in life. Is it something we’re left alone to teach ourselves, then? Do we have to make a few terrible decisions first before eventually narrowing down what we should really be up to? Thankfully, this doesn’t have to be the case. For Solomon, a pretty wise bloke, wisdom was about admitting that handling life’s situations is best done with God at the reigns (yes, that’s wordplay), not us (1 Kings 3:9). When we humble ourselves and admit that we don’t always know what’s best, God will strengthen our conscience to start knowing which way to go. Now get that journal (didn’t grab one the day before yesterday? Go grab one now... Good work.) Now, open it up and make two lists: one of what you want to learn and improve in yourself this month, and one of people or places you want to help practically and generously this month. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chr 5-7, Mark 6:45-56, Ps 119:89-96, Prov 21:20-23<br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67734&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: It's Dangerous to Go Alone (1)
content.introtext: 'Share in the troubles we have like a good soldier of Christ Jesus.' 2 Timothy 2:3 NCV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150819.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>There are certain tactics the enemy will try use to get under our skin. Perhaps you’re feeling pressure from friends and family, or your own heart and head fill you with doubts, anxieties and temptations. It’s a serious matter, but sticking close to God gives us real strength when it comes to resisting Satan. The next few days are committed to helping us triumph when the carrot of giving up is dangling in front of us. Sometimes the world’s moving goalposts when it comes to morality are a constant temptation. Jesus spent a lot of time teaching us not to be anxious about getting by, but to influence the world as ‘<em>salt</em>’ and ‘<em>light</em>’ (Matthew 5:13–14). As hard as it is, ‘<em>Religion that is pure and undefiled before God, the Father, is this: to visit orphans and widows in their affliction, and to keep oneself unstained from the world</em>.’ (James 1:27 ESV) Corruption leads to distancing from God. Wince. Good news: none of us can survive on our own. In this letter to Timothy—a young Christian preparing to face the difficulties of leading a church and staying faithful to God’s call—Paul reminds him that, just as good soldiers will share the burdens and struggles of their mates, we should do the same. It is an encouragement to know that we can call on other Christians to step up and support us, to have our backs, and to feel our pain with us. It’s our duty too to do the same for others. So, encourage someone who needs it today. Share in their troubles, like a good soldier of Christ Jesus. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chr 8-11, Mark 7:1-13, Ps 119:97-104, Prov 21:24-27 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67735&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: It's Dangerous to Go Alone (2)
content.introtext: '...Make no provision for the flesh...' Romans 13:14 NAS<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150820.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>In Paul’s letter to the Church in Rome, he brings up a hugely important factor in the battle against Satan. Something that can, but really shouldn’t, be an elephant in the room—letting ourselves indulge in things (often secretly) that don’t honour God. Each day, we’re faced with a choice to ‘<em>cast off the works of darkness</em>.’ (Romans 13:12 ESV) We’ll be blunt here: if you’ve got a niggle that something might be a hindrance to you, it probably is. We can all think of things that we don’t want to (or don’t know how to) let go of. That website? That ego–boosting slice of gossip? Those thoughts? Behind the temptation to keep hold of those things and use them, there’s a much better life that God has called us to as a ‘<em>new creation</em>’ (2 Corinthians 5:17 NIV) in Him. To back that up with some serious God–protection, it’s vital to build our relationship with God, regardless of how well or badly we feel we’re doing—He invites us to <em>‘pray in the Spirit at all times and on every occasion.</em>’ (Ephesians 6:18 NLT) This makes it harder for just–this–one–time things to slip under the radar. God doesn’t need us to be perfect (which is good, since we aren’t), but cutting back the things that hinder you will change your life. Is it time for you to find an accountability partner? Choose someone who you can be honest with. Commit to regularly keep each other in check about the thing–(or things)–to–stop–doing that came to mind today. If you can, pray for each other too. Let’s get each others’ backs. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Chr 12-15, Mark 7:14-23, Ps 119:105-112, Prov 21:28-31 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67736&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Give Up(wards)
content.introtext: 'Set your minds on things above, not on earthly things.' Colossians 3:2 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150730.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Matthew 6:24 NIV says: ‘You cannot serve both God and money.’ Right. Not a problem. Buying a few new t–shirts, when we already have a full ward-robe, isn’t ‘serving money’, is it? Possibly not. There’s nothing wrong in buying stuff. But we would ask you this… Did you ask God what He wanted you to do with that cash before splashing it? Now, this is NOT a guilt trip. Promise. It’s a reality check. Some inspiration to move forwards with. And it’s inspiration that we all need. We’ve all got to get our priorities straight. Everything we’ve got is a gift from God anyway. Our very lives, and everything in them, are given by Him, so we have a definite duty to invite Him to shine through them. That means offering everything back to Him, as soon as it lands in our lap (or, even, once we’ve worked our snowflake–patterned Christmas–in–July socks off for it). Whether it’s the $100 birthday money from granny, or the $2 you just found on the floor, God loves it when you give it back to Him. He won’t necessarily tell you to give $102 to charity/church/the homeless guy in town. He may just ask you to give a portion to one of them. But, if you take all your money to Him, you accept the risk that He may tell you to give away what’s left over, after you’ve paid your bills. In fact, scratch that, you don’t just ‘accept’ that risk. You’ll learn to delight in the God–given hazard of generosity. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Ezra 6-8, Mark 1:35-45, Ps 78:17-31, Prov 19:27-29 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67253&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Can't Touch This (Significance) (2)
content.introtext: <p>'Thank You for making me...' Psalm 139:14 NLT<br /><br /></p>
content.fulltext: <p><br />When you realise someone likes you as you are, it’s pretty great. Even when someone sheepishly says, ‘I maybe sorta kinda like you,’ it’s a massive confidence boost, right? It doesn’t even have to be romantic. It can be as straightforward as that person, the one you respect more than anyone, complimenting what you’ve done. It sticks with us when we know we’re appreciated. And that’s just when fellow humans value us! What about God? Yes, the God of creation, the same God who named the stars (Psalm 147:4) thinks more highly of you than He does the stars. Jesus says: ‘...<em>the very hairs on your head are all numbered</em>.’ (Matthew 10:30 NKJ) Your adoring fans might know your eye colour, what flavour you like your latté, or your favourite film. But the amount of hair on your head? Nah. God knows every detail about you, and loved you even before you knew Him (Ephesians 1:4). What does all this mean? God appreciates you. A lot. He values you more than you can imagine. The things that make you ‘you’ are given huge weight because of that. It’s good to remember that the best compliment, or the most alluring romance, can’t touch the significance you’ve already been given. And it’s good to remember that ‘re–member’ literally means to put back together again. Like Humpty Dumpty. So when you recollect and remember that God has made you, you’re doing something really wonderful. Particularly if you’re feeling fractured or broken today, find somewhere to be quiet and remember, and let Him put you back together again.</p> <p><br /><br />SoulFood: 1 Jn 3:11-5:21, Mark 2:23-3:6, Ps 78:56-64, Prov 20:7-10 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <em>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob &amp; Debby Gass)</em> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src="http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&amp;track=67719&amp;www=blog" alt="" width="0" height="0" /></p>

content.title: Created to Create
content.introtext: 'He...reveals His thoughts to man.' Amos 4:13 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150709.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>God is a creative God. He created something as delicately precise as atoms, neurons and quarks. He created something as grand and supersized as the IC1101 galaxy, which is estimated as 100 thousand light years across. God created Shakespeare and Picasso and your next door neighbour. The Piano Key butterfly gets a name from a stunning keyboard tattooed to its wings—again the work of Creator God. The shark, the wombat, jelly trifles, soap bubbles—they were all modelled at the hand of God. You get the idea: God is creative. Well, the Bible teaches we are made in the image of God—so if God is creative… yep, good guess, so are we. Ok, maybe you tend to colour outside the lines, sing like a strangled bullfrog or run like a demented crab—but in other unique ways you will reflect God’s creativity. Styling hair could be your thing. Or unravelling an equation. Or curling a free–kick. Or dissecting an aneurysm. Or turning over a sentence. Creativity doesn’t just happen in the art room. To some, God reveals beauty in mathematical sequences and scientific formulae; to others, He shows up in drama or paintings. However we’ve been wired; we’ve all received ‘creativity’. Not sure about that? You don’t have to class yourself as a ‘creative type’ to be able to bring ideas up that will bless people—we all have ways to reflect God’s creativity. When you tap into God’s creativity, He helps you see things not as they are, but as they can be. Today, do three creative things, in your own God–given way. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Eph 1:1-4:16, Matt 25:31-46, Ps 79, Prov 17:24-26 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67232&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Primed For Transformation
content.introtext: 'Be transformed by...renewing...your mind.' Romans 12:2 NKJ<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150710.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Romans 12 tells us to let the Holy Spirit transform us by ‘renewing...your mind.’ We can sometimes cringe at the notion of doing something that ‘isn’t me’. We tend to carve out a comfortable little possie for ourselves and that’s how the world comes to see us. And we buy into the world’s view! So when God comes along and tells the person who could never speak in class to preach to a large congregation, it’s hard to think anyone will take that seriously. Sometimes, though, we’re asked to challenge those expectations. God made us with purpose, value, dignity and worth, but along the way He’s still going to need to step in and grow us. As that emerges, of course we’re going to change. It’s practically a necessity if He’s fulfilling His purposes in us. When we don’t have the power or energy to change our own self–image, God does. In fact, whenever He calls us to do things we don’t see ourselves being capable of, He transforms us so that we can do whatever is needed. Like Op-timus Prime, we can be renewed and restored, and will come back kicking, with new Energon–like energy and power (perhaps minus the painted–on flames, though?) It’s not always easy to change others’ first impressions of us. We can don glasses but people won’t think we’re smarter. And, it can be even harder to change our own impression of ourselves. With God, though, real change happens. And those changes will eventually shine through. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Eph 4:17-6:24, Matt 26:1-13, Ps 109:1-15, Prov 17:27-28 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67233&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Kin, Not Clones (1)
content.introtext: 'May they be brought to complete unity.' John 17:23 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150711.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Truth time. We may not like to admit it, but sometimes we can subconsciously believe that we’re ‘better’ than someone else because we got this grade or that job. Our Church denomination is better or our social class is higher. John 17:23 tells us that God wants His children to be unified, and unity doesn’t allow for judgment. We can ignore lecturers and tolerate seemingly–silly ideas, with a forced smile, but our opinion of that other person has gone down. When this happens, immediately we’ve separated ourselves in spirit because of a difference of opinion. But we’re supposed to be different. God wants His children to be unified—but not by all being clones of each other. That said, ‘complete unity’ seems a tall order, doesn’t it? It is. Let’s be honest, it isn’t so easy to be unified with that guy who’s always one–upping you. We’ve all heard a bunch of talks or sermons about accepting people’s differences. We (probably) all agree with that rationally, and even in practice. What we’re likely to neglect is making accommodation in our mind for those who have a different way of thinking to us (ever got frustrated with someone who doesn’t do things your way?) That’s harder. But unity demands we learn to make room for others and respect their convictions. ‘Each one should be fully convinced in his own mind.’ (Romans 14:5 NIV) When you hear someone air an idea that opposes one of yours today, consider whether you’re actually listening, or if you’re just planning a lecture (even a silent–mental–lecture) entitled: ‘This is why you’re wrong.’ Really listen to what they say, and turn it into a fair conversation. You might learn something. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Sam 1:1-3:21, Matt 26:14-25, Ps 109:16-31, Prov 18:1-3 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67234&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Kin, Not Clones (2)
content.introtext: 'Have fervent love for one another.' 1 Peter 4:8 NKJ<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150712.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>‘Do nothing out of selfish ambition…value others above yourselves.’ (Philippians 2:3 NIV) You’ve heard it a hundred times: the golden rule, love your neighbour, etc. So why do people still talk about valuing others above yourself when everyone’s heard it a million times? Well, your Mum told you that sprouts were good for you a million times but did you eat them? Yeah. See what we mean? Christians talk about loving each other all the time because it’s important. It’s one thing to know you should be unified, it’s another to put aside pettiness and actually work for it. What we do affects other people whether we think about it or not, and quite often, when we inadvertently hurt someone, we feel awful. Or we can try to justify it: We were ‘only following the rules’. But when somebody else’s action affects us, we don’t tend to offer the same courtesy we offer ourselves. We attribute blame and assume that we know that their intention was to hurt us. For some reason, we don’t expect from others the same human weaknesses that we have. Jesus told us that love trumps everything. Paul said, ‘Everything is permissible—but not everything is beneficial.’ (1 Corinthians 10:23 NIV) He was talking about doing things that are ok but that other people might find offensive. And he basically says: think twice... then think again. Holding onto the view ‘but I did nothing wrong’ for the sake of offended pride is not on. Holding onto the spirit of Scripture that Jesus taught (again, love) is on. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: Gen 14:18-20, Ps 110, Heb 5:5-11 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67235&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Doing vs. Being
content.introtext: 'You cannot be fruitful unless you remain in Me.' John 15:4 NLT<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150713.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Jesus tells us straight up that our successes lie in Him. End of story. Unless we’re doing things in His name and with His backing, it’s not going to work out. We have a problem when we try to emulate Jesus, without Jesus. A lot goes into the running of a Church and, when you get to a certain point in your Church life, you might think about helping out. That’s brilliant. It’s a great thing to want to use your talent with technology to set up the sound equipment, or to use your awesome coffee–making–and–smiling–at–the–same–time skills in joining the refreshment team. Sometimes, though, we can get caught up in wanting to help. Suddenly, we’re on twelve different rotas and we never actually get to sit and listen to a sermon. We’re doing all these things for God, but if we’re not building our relationship with Him, then we lose track of why we’re doing those things in the first place. James 2:26 famously says that ‘faith without works is dead’. But works without faith aren’t alive, either. They become a façade, sometimes even an at-tempt to buy favour with God! It doesn’t matter if you look like a Super Christian outwardly, if you’re not right with God inwardly. When we stop doing things in Him, we can’t succeed, and our efforts become meaningless. Spend an hour today not doing anything but waiting on God. No matter how much work you have to do, clear your schedule just for one hour. Sit with your Bible and a pen, and maybe some Spirit–focussed music. But just *be* in that hour, don’t worry about *doing* anything. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Sam 3:22-7:17, Matt 26:26-35, Ps 118:1-9, Prov 18:4-6 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67236&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Wait for it...
content.introtext: 'The Lord has need of him.' Luke 19:34 NKJ<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150714.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>When you’re a Christian it’s less–than–great not knowing how God wants to use you. When people all around are talking about their callings and all’s quiet on the Heaven–front for you, it can be disheartening. But remember that story about the colt Jesus rode into Jerusalem? That colt had never been ridden and was tied to a tree, overlooked and underestimated by the people around him. But Jesus had ‘need of him’ and knew the right time to call for him. Now, you’re not a baby horse (or a baby goat. Neigh, we kid you not), but the same applies in your life. You’ve heard that God has a plan for you and you may be wondering what that is (or not; if you already know, then that’s prettyyyy cool). However we have to remember that plans run on a schedule and, unlike ours, God’s plans tend to stay on schedule. He’s going to call you when He knows the time is right. That can be difficult to accept, but let’s face it, God’s plan is better than anything we could come up with. Jesus was never influenced by other people’s opinions. It didn’t matter that the colt was overlooked or the prostitute was looked down upon or that everyone hated the taxman, Jesus still loved them and had a purpose for them. He knows your value better than others do, and better than you do. So, try this reminder: when you’re making tea tonight, stop cooking halfway through and see if you’d want to eat it. Bet you’d rather wait until it’s cooked and ready. Some things you just have to wait for. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Sam 7:18-11:27, Matt 26:36-46, Ps 118:10-18, Prov 18:7-9 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67237&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>

content.title: Muscle Memory Prayer (1)
content.introtext: 'Whatever you ask for in prayer, believe...and it will be yours.' Mark 11:24 NIV<br /><br /><hr id="system-readmore" /><br />{mp3remote}http://www.thewordfortoday.com.au/media/twftaudio/20150715.mp3{/mp3remote}<br /><p>Let’s pray. Hands together. Sound like a familiar instinct? If you were taught to pray as a kid, it’s probably muscle memory. You likely also felt that rush of rebellion as you sneakily took a peek around the assembly hall to see if anyone ‘wasn’t praying right.’ But you’ve probably realised that God doesn’t care if your hands are together, at your sides, or raised in the air. Prayer isn’t about hand placement. There’s a cool thought from William Ward: ‘We stamp and address an envelope and send it on its way with complete confidence that it will reach its destination. Yet we wonder and even doubt if our prayers will be heard by an ever–present, ever–loving God.’ When Peter told a man who couldn’t walk to get up and go, it didn’t happen because he thought, half–heartedly, ‘Meh, might as well give it a go.’ It happened because he knew that God has real power, and would answer his prayer. God rewarded Peter’s sincere faith. We can get caught up in the words of a prayer or the length of it. It can be hard to remember that prayer is just a way of telling God that we’re ready and believing. Peter simply said, ‘In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, rise up and walk’ (Acts 3:6 ESV), and it happened. God knows already what we want to say. So pray in a way you’re comfortable with, and keep an eye out for answers. </p><br /><br />SoulFood: 2 Sam 12:1-14:20, Matt 26:47-56, Ps 118:19-29, Prov 18:10-12 <br /><br /><small>word4U2day <i>(an adaptation of The Word for Today authored by Bob & Debby Gass)</i> is published under licence by UCB Australia. 2015 UCB International Ltd</small><img src='http://word.ucbmedia.com/includes/track/track.php?b=4&track=67238&www=blog' height='0' width='0' alt=''>
